metadata.title: Magnetization plateaus behaviors in a nano-graphene bilayer structure_ A Monte Carlo study

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Physica E: Low-dimensional Systems and Nanostructures
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/physe
Magnetization plateaus behaviors in a nano-graphene bilayer structure: A Monte Carlo study
Wei Wanga,∗, Qi Lia, Ming-ze Wangb, Ye Mab, An-bang Guoa, Te Huanga
a School of Science, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China b School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano-graphene bilayer Magnetization plateaus Magnetization Internal energy Monte Carlo simulation
A B S T R A C T
The Monte Carlo simulation as an effective method has been applied to analyze the magnetization plateaus behaviors of a nano-graphene bilayer structure in a longitudinal magnetic field. The influences of the single-ion anisotropies, the exchange couplings and temperature on the magnetization plateaus have been discussed. We find that the single-ion anisotropies, the exchange couplings and the external magnetic field play important role in magnetization plateaus behaviors and spin configurations. Multiple magnetization plateaus have been found, originating from the competition among different physical parameters. Furthermore, the effects of the single-ion anisotropies and the exchange couplings on the magnetization and the internal energy of the system have been examined in the presence of the external magnetic field.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, the study of graphene has evolved into a developing subject of great interests. In view of its unique benzene's six-membered rings, graphene has been considered as the thinnest and lightest materials with two-dimensional structure. With the improvement of preparation technology, nano-graphene has pushed forward the progress of solar cells [1], environmental science [2], magnetoresistive random access memory devices [3], field-effect transistors [4], magnetic storage [5] and chemical engineering [6]. In experiment, the investigations of nano-graphene have attracted great attention. Up to now, nano-graphene has been fabricated by various chemical methods. Based on the method of exfoliation-inserting layers again-inflation, the light transmittance of the nano-graphene system has been improved obviously [7]. By using the technique of making high concentration of carbon source at low pressure and then cooling slowly, the homogeneous double-layer graphene has been synthesized successfully [8].
Naturally, graphene is a weakly correlated (semi-)metal, which makes the use of pristine graphene for new nanoelectric and nanophotonic device applications face some obstacles due to the absence of the gap in its band structure. Recently, intense interest has been directed to developing directions for modifying electronic structure and introducing magnetism in this nonmagnetic material. In particular, much progress has been made in exploring and understanding the magnetism of the graphene single layer or bilayer in both experimental
and theoretical research. In experiment, magnetism has been found in doped and defective graphene [9]. Ferrimagnetic ordering has been induced in multilayered graphene just by randomly removing C atoms [10]. A series of the excellent magnetic properties have been discovered in single layer or bi-layer graphene rotated relative to the Ni(111) lattice and Fe (5 nm)/MnAs (100 nm) bilayers epitaxially grown on GaAs (100) [11,12]. The topological phases applied to an external magnetic field have been obtained in the biased ferromagnetic graphene bilayer [13]. Moreover, another effective way is cutting the graphene sheet along a straight line forms one dimensional graphene nanoribbons with armchair or zigzag edges, which show different magnetic and electronic properties [14–16].
In order to explore the nature of magnetism for different nanographene structure, many theoretical investigations have been carried out with different models and numerical methods. In remarkable, multiple spin states have been applied to discussing the magnetic mechanism for nano-graphene-like molecules such as C48H24 and C59N5H22 graphene molecule in recent years. This is the first successful approach applied to explain ferromagnetism. By the predictions of molecular orbital calculations and the density function theory, the highest spin state of S=3/2 corresponds to the lowest energy, which is considered to be steadier. Thus for C48H24 graphene molecule, up and down spins are arranged in turn [17]. This is why the system can exhibit an antiferromagnetic exchange coupling between spins. Whereas in the C59N5H22 graphene molecule, five unpaired electrons provide the

As is well-known, the Ising model as one of the basic models of statistical physics has been successfully extended to describe various magnetic nanosystems and plays a significant role in understanding magnetic phase transitions and electric polarization behaviors of spin systems. Based on these facts, the nano-graphene structure can be rather well described by the mixed-spin Ising model, which is considered to be reasonable. We should mention that, within various extended Ising models, the effects of various physical parameters such as the anisotropy, the exchange coupling, the longitudinal magnetic field and temperature on magnetic performances of different graphene structures have been examined deeply. Based on Monte Carlo (MC) simulation, R. Masrour et al. have studied the influences of the defects, size, longitudinal magnetic field and crystal-field on the magnetizations, susceptibilities, blocking temperatures and hysteresis loops of the mixedspin (3/2, 5/2) Ising nano-graphene system with single-layer [19,20] and double-layer [21–24] as well as nanoisland structure [25]. It is found that a higher mixed-spin (7/2, 3) Ising model has been proposed to describe the bilayer decorated graphene structure in a recent Monte Carlo study. The ground state phase diagrams and the hysteresis loops have been discussed in detail [26]. A mixed-spin (3/2, 5/2) Ising ferrimagnetic system has been applied to examining the effects of nextnearest neighbors exchange interactions and crystal field anisotropy on the critical and compensation behaviors of a graphene layer by means of Monte Carlo simulations [27]. Recent Monte Carlo investigations have been directed to the nano-graphene layer by modeling the mixedspin Ising system with higher order exchange couplings [28–32]. It was found that the Ising model with four-spin interaction can exhibit rich critical phenomena and compensation behavior. More interestingly, the magnetic properties of the spin 5/2 Blume-Emery-Griffiths model on a nano-graphene layer has been discussed by the Monte Carlo simulation [33]. It is reported that at low temperature, the magnetizations show the magnetization plateaus, which come from multiple spin states in the nano-graphene. By the effective-field theory (EFT), excellent magnetic performances of a nano-graphene bilayer have been studied in the external magnetic field based on the transverse Ising model [34]. It has been obtained that exchange couplings, single-ion anisotropies, the transverse field and the external magnetic field can strongly affect the magnetization, the susceptibility as well as the blocking temperature for the nano-graphene bilayer. By using the mean field theory (MFT), magnetic properties and ground phase diagrams of nano-graphene have been obtained [35]. L. Bahmad et al. have also investigated the effect of surface magnetic field on the graphene structure within the MFT [36]. Guo et al. have discussed the spin-wave spectra and sublattice magnetizations of a graphene-like bilayer with four-sublattice used by the retarded Green's function and the linear spin-wave approximation [37]. Y. Mohammadi et al. have studied the local moment of graphene bilayer in depth with the Anderson impurity model [38]. Based on molecular dynamic simulations, it is reported that the hybrid graphene system can display the higher Curie point as well as ferromagnetic behaviors in the ground state [39]. By the density-functional theory, the effects of cobalt-vacancy defect complexes on the magnetic and electronic characteristics in the graphene system have been analyzed [40].
The mixed-spin Ising systems applied to the longitudinal magnetic field have been studied for so many years in theoretical investigations. The results revealed the interesting magnetic behaviors of low-dimensional systems at low temperature, such as magnetization plateaus, spin ladders and exchange bias [41,42]. The 2S + 1 magnetization plateaus may emerge with the increase of the longitudinal magnetic field toward the saturation value hS, and meanwhile, the proper condition sm= integer for appearing magnetization plateaus within the longitudinal magnetic field has been obtained effectively [43]. The existence of the magnetization plateaus may be originated from the competitions among the anisotropy, temperature and magnetic field in
the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic mixed film system [44]. Through the EFT, the importance of the crystal-field to the magnetization plateaus has been emphasized for the ferrimagnetic nanoparticle system [45]. It has been found that the system can display the 2S + 1 magnetization plateaus for different anisotropies, but it dissatisfies the 2S + 1 criterion for the stronger anisotropy. A. Kitazawa et al. have discussed magnetization plateaus of the spin-3/2 chain system under the effects of single-ion anisotropies [46]. By means of the densitymatrixre normalization group calculations as well as the molecular-field theory, the magnetic characteristics of a ferrimagnetic mixed-spin (1, 3/2) Ising nano-system have been examined within homogenous singleion anisotropies [47]. By using transfer-matrix method, the magnetization plateaus of a finite chain have been discovered, due to the energy competition between anisotropy and the external magnetic field [48]. By the MC simulation, it is feasible to analyze the magnetization plateaus of the triangular lattices [49]. Furthermore, a variety of experimental results on the magnetization plateaus have been observed in diverse systems, for instance, the quasione-dimensional Ni-compounds [50], the quasi two-dimensional compounds SrCu2(BO3)2 [51], FexMg1xCl12 [52] and La0.67-xAxCa0.33MnO3 [53].
In our previous work, we have employed MC simulation to examine magnetic and thermodynamic properties of the nano-graphene bilayer system under the influence of the external magnetic field [54,55]. Although so much effort was devoted to investigating the magnetic properties of nano-graphene bilayer, the magnetization plateau behaviors have not been thrown into more concerns. Therefore, in this paper, we will study the magnetization plateaus of a nano-graphene bilayer by MC simulation. Whether the nano-graphene bilayer system expresses richer magnetization plateau behaviors? Does the nano-graphene system also satisfy the 2S + 1 criterion? This paper is organized as follows. The related model and the method can be given in Section 2. The results obtained from the simulation are presented in Section 3. In Section 4, final conclusions are attained.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: In this section, we take Jab as the reduced unit of temperature and energy, then fix |Jab|= 1. Since the intralayer exchange coupling in the upper layer is antiferromagnetic between sublattices A and B, we suppose the initial directions of spins in the bottom layer SiC jDz ( ) , and the spins of sublattices A in the upper layer σiAz as well as the longitudinal magnetic field h are along the positive z-direction, but the spins of sublattices B in the upper layerσjBz are along the negative z-direction. First, we shall look into the effects of different single-ion anisotropies, exchange couplings and temperatures on the magnetization plateaus for the nano-graphene bilayer. Typical results are shown in Figs. 3–12. Second, the effects of physical parameters on the magnetization and internal energy are discussed, as presented in Figs. 13–15.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effects of single-ion anisotropies on the magnetization plateaus of the system and the sublattices
sections.text:
First of all, the influences of the single-ion anisotropies Da and Db on the magnetization plateaus of the system and the sublattices have been analyzed, as demonstrated in Figs. 3–7. We have plotted the total magnetization M and the magnetization of sublattices A, B, C and DM1, M2, M3 and M4 are as the function of the longitudinal magnetic field h in Fig. 3a–d for Da=0.5, 2.5 when Db=0.5, Ja=-0.6, Jb=0.8 and T=0.05. From Fig. 3a, it is clearly seen the existence of four magnetization plateaus M=1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0 for Da =0.5. The first and the second dot lines counting from left correspond to the magnetization plateausM=1.5 andM=1.75 that are named the critical magnetization plateaus hC1 (=4.4) and hC2 (=5.4), while the last dot line corresponding to the magnetization plateaus M=2.0 is called the saturation magnetic field hS (=6.4). The reason for magnetization plateaus can be illustrated by multiple spin states configuration of sublattices, as shown in Fig. 3b. It is found that the M1, M3 and M4 are always at spin states =σ 3/2iAz and =S 5/2iC jDz ( ) , respectively. The M2 may take spin states = ± ±σ 3/2, 1/2jBz . For example, by the equation (7), we can obtain four values of magnetization plateaus in Fig. 3a, M=(3/2-3/2+5/2+5/2)/ 4=1.25, M=(3/2-1/2+5/2+5/2)/4=1.5, M=(3/2+1/2+5/2+5/ 2)/4=1.75 and M=(3/2+3/2+5/2+5/2)/4=2.0. Comparing Fig. 3a and b, it is not difficult to find that the variation of M2 is entirely responsible for that of M. Thus, for the M and M2, the number of magnetization plateaus satisfies the criterion of 2S+1=2×3/2+1=4,
because the four spin states of sublattice B are = ± ±σ 3/2, 1/2jBz . It just accords with previous theoretical studies [43–45]. From Fig. 3c, one can also observe four magnetization plateaus for stronger Da=2.5, while the width of the magnetization plateaus becomes larger, suggesting that the values of the critical and saturation magnetic fields are varying. The width of the magnetization plateaus can be obtained from the vertical distance between two adjacent critical magnetic fields or the last critical and saturation fields. The value of hC1 decreases from 4.4 to 1.8, and hS increases from 6.4 to 10.4, while hC2 is almost unchangeable (hc2=5.4). As plotted in Fig. 3d, one can observe that, the M3 and M4 still maintain constant, but the M1 of sublattice A has one jump rather than an invariant and the M2 has only two jumps, which
are different from that of Fig. 3b. It is noticed that the values of the M1 and M2 start from 0.5 and -0.5 at h=0 for Da=2.5. This is because the spins of sublattices A and B are favorite to stay at the low spin states =σ 1/2iAz and = −σ 1/2jBz for stronger anisotropy Da in order to meet the demand of the lowest energy in the system. It is clear that the jumps of the M1 at hC1 =1.86 and M2 at hC2= 5.4 in Fig. 3d correspond to the two jumps of M in Fig. 3c. Therefore, the number of magnetization plateaus comes from the cooperation ofM1 andM2 rather than only the contribution of M2, which is completely diverse from the case of Fig. 3a and b. The results can be explained by the competitions between three physical parameters including the Da, h and Ja. The external magnetic field h tends to force the spins of sublattices A and B to align along its direction, whereas the antiferromagnetic exchange coupling Ja tends to maintain them in antiparallel alignment. On the other hand, the increasing of |Da| favors the low states of the spins, while h favors the high spin states. The phenomenon is similar to that obtained in other studies such as nano-graphene layer [33], a finite Ising chain [48], graphene nanoland [57] with EFT.
In order to clarify deeply how the hC1, hC2 and hS change with Da, we present the phase diagram of the magnetization plateaus in the (Da, h) plane when Db=0.5, Ja=-0.6, Jb=0.8 and T=0.05, as shown in Fig. 4. Some symbol lines stand for the values of the critical magnetic fields hC1 and hC2 and the saturation hS. Besides, the diagram is divided into three parts by two vertical dot lines. When the value of Da increases, the hC1 decreases linearly until to the turning point at Da=2.1, then starts to increase linearly for Da<3.5 and maintains unchangeable for Da≥3.6. The hC2 keeps constant at first, then it increases linearly when Da>3.5, while the hs always increases closely linearly. It is well-known that the strong anisotropy can make the sublattices to lie in the lower spin states. For the variation of hC1, we can notice one turning point at Da=2.1, corresponding to the appearance of low spin states of sublattices A and B =σ 1/2iAz and = −σ 1/2jBz , while the other turning point can be found at Da=3.5, suggesting that the spin state of sublattice A is independence of increasing Da. On the
contrary, the spin state of sublattice B depends on the increasing Da, which leads to the existence of the same turning point at Da=3.5 for the hC2. Finally, the behavior of the hS comes from the dominant effect of external magnetic field. These interesting variations of the hC1, hC2 and hS reflect the change of not only the width in plateaus, but also the
spin states in sublattices. And the specific spin states of four sublattices and total magnetization for different areas under the effects of Da and h are shown in the Table 2.
Next, we will discuss the influence of the anisotropy Db on the magnetization plateaus. TheM,M1,M2,M3 andM4 as the function of h
for Db=2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 4.0 when Da=0.5, Ja=-0.6, Jb=0.8 and T=0.05 are plotted in Figs. 5, 6a-d. Compared with the influences of Da, we discover more abundant magnetization plateaus behaviors. In Fig. 5a, when Db=2.0, there are five magnetization plateaus M=0.75, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0, corresponding to hC1=1.1, hC2=4.3, hC3 =5.4 and hS=6.3. From Fig. 5b, it is clearly seen that theM1 andM2 have similar changes as those in Fig. 3, but the M3 and M4 have one synchronous jump from 1.5 to 2.5 at hC1, Namely the M3 and M4 take two spin 3/2 and 5/2 states in the whole range of h. Therefore, the plateau with M=0.75 is attributed to the spin state configuration =σ 3/2iAz , = −σ 3/2jBz and =S 3/2iC jDz ( ) . Further increasing Db to 2.5, an additional magnetization plateau M=0.25 has been observed in Fig. 5c, so the system exhibits six magnetization plateaus with hC1=0.6, hC2=3.1, hC3=4.4, hC4=5.4 and hS=6.3. The existence of M=0.25 can be explained from Fig. 5d. The increasing of Db force the spins of sublattices C and D to stay at lower spin-1/2 state under the weak magnetic field. Thus, the first plateau comes from M=0.25 comes from spin configuration =σ 3/2iAz , = −σ 3/2jBz and =S 1/2iC jDz ( ) .
On increasing Db, we can discover more interesting magnetization plateau behaviors, as plotted in Fig. 6a–d. From Fig. 6a, seven magnetization plateaus exist at M=0.25, 0.75, 1.0, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0 for Db=3.0, corresponding to hC1=1.5, hC2=3.2, hC3=4.3, hC4=5.3, hC5=7.05 and hS=7.8. Compared to above results, one can notice
another plateau with M=1.0, which is analyzed by Fig. 6b. With Db increasing, the M3 and M4 are more likely to stay at low spin states, thus the plateau M=1.0 comes from the spin state configuration =σ 3/2iAz , = −σ 1/2jBz and =S 3/2iC jDz ( ) . On the other hand, with h increasing, the M3 and M4 have an asynchronous jump from M=1.5 to 2.5 under the strong h and the M3 jumps earlier than M4, which is different from those of Fig. 5. We can remark that the multiple magnetization plateaus behavior originates from not only the cooperation among different sublattice magnetizations, but also the competition between Db and h.
Interestingly, more magnetization plateaus are found for stronger Db, as illustrated in Fig. 6c. When Db=4.0, the system displays eight magnetization plateaus M=0.25, 0.50, 0.75, 1.0, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0 with hC1=2.3, hC2=3.2, hC3=4.3, hC4=5.4, hC5=6.1, hC6=11.05 and hS=11.8 respectively. As shown in Fig. 6d, the spin state configuration =σ 3/2iAz , = −σ 1/2jBz and =S 1/2iC jDz ( ) is responsible for the more plateau with M=0.50 in Fig. 6c. It is worth noting that the M3 and M4 have two asynchronous jumps from M=0.5 to 1.5 and M=1.5 to 2.5, and twice jumps of M3 are earlier than M4. Analysis for the asynchronous behaviors between the M3 and M4 can be attributed to different surrounding environment of sublattices C and D besides the competition between the anisotropies and the magnetic field. In addition, the above results demonstrate that the number of the magnetization plateaus is very sensitive to the anisotropy Db. Although the
number of the magnetization plateaus of the single sublattice in some conditions satisfies the 2S+1 principle, the number of the total magnetization plateaus may dissatisfy the 2S+1 principle. This is because of the complexity of model structure as well as the multiple spin states of sublattices depending on various physical parameters. As a result, the 2S+1 principle may be only applicable for the situation of the spin variation in one sublattice. We should mention that similar phenomenon about the dissatisfaction of the 2S+1 criterion in the number of the magnetization plateaus has been observed in the hexagonal nanoparticle for the strong anisotropies [45] and the Zigzag graphene nanoribbon [58].
Fig. 7 shows the phase diagram of the magnetization plateaus for
the positive Db when Da=0.5, Ja=-0.6, Jb=0.8 and T=0.05. It is found that the phase diagram is divided into five parts by four vertical dot lines. From left to right, the number of the magnetization plateaus becomes more and more, showing four to eight magnetization plateaus. When Db≤ 1.75, the hC1, hC2 and hS maintain constant, which is determined by the change of M2. This is because that Db mainly affects the spin states of sublattices C and D while has little effect on sublattice B. So the spin states of sublattices B depend on magnetic fields rather than Db. When the values of Db continues to increase, the values of the critical and saturation magnetic fields start to increase closely linearly in every part. This is because the synchronized or asynchronous jumps of the M3 and M4 lead to the more magnetization plateaus in the M. From another perspective, the existence of magnetization plateaus is due to the fact that the magnetizations of sublattices have different
dependencies of various physical parameters. Namely, the spins of different sublattices can take multiple spin states, depending on different anisotropies and the external magnetic field. The results are similar to those obtained in graphene monolayer with EFT [59]. The detailed spin states of four sublattices and corresponding total magnetization for different areas under the effects of Db and h are displayed in Table 3. Through the above analysis, it is found that the anisotropy has a significant influence on the magnetization plateaus behaviors by controlling the spin states of the sublattices. It should be mentioned that the importance of the anisotropy on the magnetization plateaus has been focused on recent theoretical studies, such as for a Blume-Capel model on the Bethe lattice [43], a frustrated dipolar array [60], a class
of exactly solvable Ising-Heisenberg chains [61] and a 2D boron [62].

sections.heading: 3.2. Effects of exchange couplings on the magnetization plateaus of the system and the sublattices
sections.text:
Let us discuss how the exchange couplings Ja and Jb affect the magnetization plateaus of the system and the sublattices, as plotted in Figs. 8–11. Fig. 8a and b shows the M, M1, M2, M3 and M4 are as the function of the h for Ja=−0.4, −1.5 when Jb=0.8, Da=0.5, Db=1.5 and T=0.05. In Fig. 8a, when Ja changes from −0.4 to −1.5, the system exhibits four same magnetization plateaus M=1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0, and the M curve shifts towards the stronger magnetic
field, with the values of critical and saturation fields also increasing. Namely, hC1= 3.5, hC2= 4.6 and hS= 5.6 for Ja=−0.4, while hC1= 8.4, hC2= 9.5 and hS= 10.5 for Ja=−1.5. This phenomenon can be explained as follows: when the exchange coupling is strengthened, it is difficult for the spins to flip in order to overcome the strong exchange coupling energy. Thus, the stronger magnetic field is needed to promote such flip for spins. As shown in Fig. 8b, it is clearly seen that with |Ja| increasing, the M1, M3 and M4 still maintain unchangeable spin states, only the M2 has four spin −3/2, −1/2, 1/2 and 3/2 states. The result presents that only M2 is sensitive to the Ja for certain parameters.
Fig. 9 shows the phase diagram of magnetization plateaus for the negative Ja with Jb=0.8, Da=0.5, Db=1.5 and T=0.05. With Ja increasing, the hC1, hC2 and hS vary almost linearly. We can find that the width of all the magnetization plateaus is almost equal. This confirms that the increasing of Ja only make the M curves shift to the right without changing the width of the magnetization plateaus, as observed in Fig. 8a. It can be concluded that the number of the magnetization plateaus behavior seems to insensitive to Ja. We provide the Table 4 about the specific spin states of four sublattices and the total magnetization under the effects of Ja and h.
Next, we discuss the effect of the exchange coupling Jb on the magnetization plateaus, as plotted in Fig. 10a–d for Jb= 0.3, 0.55 when Ja=−0.6, Da=0.5, Db=1.5 and T=0.05. From Fig. 10a, one can know that, for small value of Jb (=0.3), there are six magnetization plateaus M=0.25, 0.75, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0 with hC1= 0.8, hC2= 2.8, hC3= 4.3, hC4=5.4 and hS=6.4. It is observed from
Fig. 10b that the M3 and M4 have two synchronous jumps at h=0.7 and h=2.8, namely the spins of sublattices C and D may take the spin 1/2, 3/2 and 5/2 states in turn when h increases from 0 to 10. Meanwhile the M1 and M2 display such similar spin states as those in Fig. 10 b and d. Further increasing Jb to 0.55, one can find from Fig. 10c that the system present five magnetization plateaus M=0.75, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.0 with hC1= 1.1, hC2= 4.3, hC3= 5.3 and hS= 6.4. Compared to Fig. 10a, the less plateau with M=0.25 is found because the increasing of Jbmakes the spins of sublattices C and D to stay at the spin 3/2 state in the range of small h, as shown in Fig. 10d. The result shows that the spin state of sublattices C and D are sensitive to the Jb. Physically, the smaller exchange coupling Jb is propitious to the low spin states for sublattices C and D because the spins become more easier to flip against the weaker exchange coupling energy. With h increasing, the spins may change from low to high spin states, depending on the competition between the Jb and h. The similar behaviors have been observed in the studies with the EFT [57,59,62–64] and MC simulation [33,58,65].
Fig. 11 presents the phase diagram of magnetization plateaus for the Jb when Ja=-0.6, Da=0.5, Db=1.5 and T=0.05. The diagram is divided into three parts by two dot lines. From left to right, the number of the magnetization plateaus is reduced one in turn from six to four. Under the influence of small Jb, the spins of the sublattices C and D lie in the low spin 1/2 state for 0.2< Jb≤0.45and spin 3/2 state for 0.45< Jb<0.7. By comparison of the effects of Jb and Db on the magnetization plateaus behavior, there seems to be opposite. Namely, the smaller values of Jb and the larger values of |Db| tend to make the

sections.heading: 3.3. Effects of temperature on the magnetization plateaus
sections.text: Fig. 12 displays the influence of the temperature on the total magnetization plateaus behaviors for choosing four typical values of T=0.05, 0.25, 0.5 and 0.8 with Ja=−0.6, Jb=0.8, Da=2.5 and Db=0.5. As T increases, magnetization plateaus become smoother and finally may disappear at T=0.8, demonstrating that the temperature can weaken the magnetization plateaus behavior obviously. The similar phenomenon is also found in the nano-graphene structures [26,33,57–59] and other nano-systems [66–70].

sections.heading: 3.4. Effects of the anisotropy and exchange coupling on the magnetization and the energy
sections.text:
In order to better understand the relationship between the magnetization plateaus and the internal energy of the system, the Magnetic field h dependence of internal energy U for different anisotropies Da, Db and exchange couplings Ja, Jb are presented in Fig. 13a–d. From four sub-figures, one can notice that each U displays a decreasing trend with h increasing from the zero to the saturated field. This means that increasing h is easier to force the spins to prefer the higher spin states so that the system becomes more stable. Moreover, it is clearly seen that U changes discontinuously with some turning points at the locations of the critical magnetic fields hC and saturation magnetic fields hS, which just correspond to the occurring places of the magnetization plateaus observed in previous Figs. 3–12. From Fig. 13a and b, one can observe that increasing either Da or Db may improve U. This result is due to the fact that the strong anisotropy tends to make the system disordered. In Fig. 13c, it is interesting that there is an intersection point between the two U curves, which is called as the special value of magnetic field hk. When h increases from 0 to 12, for h < hk, the U decreases with |Ja| increasing, whereas for h > hk, the contrary situation occurs. The U increases with |Ja| increasing. This phenomenon may be attributed to the competition between the ferrimagnetic exchange coupling and the magnetic field. In Fig. 13d, as we expected, the increasing of Jb will contribute to the decrease of U because it is more difficult for the spins to change from high spin states to low states under the effect of stronger ferromagnetic exchange coupling.
Finally, let us focus on the common effects of the anisotropies from both two sublattices on the magnetization and the internal energy of the system with fixed Ja=−0.6, Jb=0.8, h=0.1 and T=0.5, as shown in Fig. 14a and b. From Fig. 14a, one can notice that the magnetization M decreases with increasing the value of Db from 0 to 5.0, while seems insensitive to the variation of Da. This phenomenon comes from the fact that the stronger Db can stabilize the spins of sublattices in the lower spin states, leading to the drop of M. It is concluded that the effect of Db on the magnetization is stronger that of Da. In Fig. 14b, we can see that the U increases with Da and Db increasing only for small values of Da and Db. For stronger Db, U maintains almost unchangeable whatever Da (> 1) changes.
Fig. 15a and b shows the M and U of the system as a function of the exchange couplings Ja and Jb with Da=0.5, Db=1.5, h=0.1 and T=0.5. From Fig. 15a, we can see that increasing both Jb and |Ja|
(< 0.5) will enhance the M because the stronger exchange couplings make the spins flip more difficultly. It is clearly observed that the effect of Jb on M is stronger than that of Ja. This is because the values of the spins in the bottom layer ( =S 5/2iC jDz ( ) ) are larger than those in the upper layer = ±σ( 3/2)iA jBz ( ) . In Fig. 15b, the U decreases with |Ja| and Jb increasing, suggesting the system is in a more stable state. In a certain sense, the effects of the exchange couplings (Ja, Jb) on the M and U are opposite to those of the anisotropies (Da, Db). These similar results have been observed in graphene monolayer [28,29], graphene bilayer [55] and other nano-systems such as hexagonal-type magnetic nanowires [71–73], nanoparticles [74,75] and nanoisland [76] with hexagonal core/shell structure.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: Based on the Monte Carlo simulation, we have studied the magnetization plateaus behaviors of a nano-graphene bilayer structure under the influences of the single-ion anisotropies, the exchange couplings and temperature in a longitudinal magnetic field. The multiple magnetization plateaus behaviors can reflect the multiple spin states of sublattices, originating from the competitions among the anisotropies, exchange couplings and external magnetic field as well as the cooperation among different sublattice magnetizations. The number of the total magnetization plateaus may dissatisfy the 2S + 1 criterion for some cases. It is found that the Db and Jb have the greater impact on the magnetization plateaus behaviors than Da and Ja. Of course, we admit this present work are mainly stems from the theoretical interests. But we look forward to motivating more theoretical and experimental explorations for the nano-graphene in future.

metadata.abstractText: The Monte Carlo simulation as an effective method has been applied to analyze the magnetization plateaus behaviors of a nano-graphene bilayer structure in a longitudinal magnetic field. The influences of the single-ion anisotropies, the exchange couplings and temperature on the magnetization plateaus have been discussed. We find that the single-ion anisotropies, the exchange couplings and the external magnetic field play important role in magnetization plateaus behaviors and spin configurations. Multiple magnetization plateaus have been found, originating from the competition among different physical parameters. Furthermore, the effects of the single-ion anisotropies and the exchange couplings on the magnetization and the internal energy of the system have been examined in the presence of the external magnetic field.
